Today I introduced a bill that would authorize the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to pay for the transportation of a deceased veteran’s remains to a state-owned or tribal-owned veterans cemetery. The VA is currently only authorized to transport such remains to a national veterans cemetery.  Our veterans stood ready to answer their country’s call with their lives, and we should treat their deaths with dignity. If the VA is authorized to spend the money necessary to send a deceased veteran to a national cemetery, then it makes sense for it also to pay to send these heroes to a state-owned veterans cemetery closer to home. My legislation would also decrease the burden on distraught families of deceased veterans that may be forced to travel to a far-away internment in a national cemetery.  To read the text of my bill, visit this link: https://banks.house.gov/sites/banks.house.gov/files/wysiwyg_uploaded/Transportation%20of%20Deceased%20Veterans%20to%20Veterans%27%20Cemeteries%20Bill%20Text.pdf

When I asked northeast Indiana to send me to Congress last year, I made a commitment that I would fight to fully repeal Obamacare. I also pledged to support a replacement plan centered around free market health care reforms that lower costs, empower individuals and increase competition. I hope to support a repeal and replacement plan that achieves these important goals.   I commend President Trump, Speaker Ryan and the House leadership team for their hard work and inclusive approach to this debate. While the replacement plan released last night contains positive reforms like a permanent repeal of the medical device tax and repeal of the individual mandate, I have concerns about several aspects of the bill. These include: the overall cost of the plan, the length of time it takes to repeal many Obamacare taxes, the possible creation of a new entitlement program and whether essential pro-life protections will be maintained. I will carefully study this legislation and evaluate how these concerns are addressed as this bill moves through the legislative process.

On April 29 I will host a Service Academy Day at the Fort Wayne Air National Guard Base for local students who are interested in attending one of the five service academies. Each of the five service academies offers an extremely valuable education. Students who attend Academy Day will have the ability to meet with representatives from each institution and talk with my staff and me about the academy nomination process.   The Academy Day will be held at the Air National Guard Base at 3005 Ferguson Road in Fort Wayne. Representatives from the following service academies will be present: • United States Military Academy (West Point, NY) • United States Naval Academy (Annapolis, MD) • United States Coast Guard Academy (New London, CT) • United States Merchant Marine Academy (Kings Point, NY) • United States Air Force Academy (Colorado Springs, CO)  The representatives will speak about the academies and be available to answer students’ questions afterwards. Doors will open for registration at 10:00 a.m. and the event is scheduled to last until 12:30 p.m.  In order to gain entry to the base on Academy Day, students and their guests must RSVP by April 20 to Tinisha Weigelt at RepBanksAcademies@mail.house.gov with their names, driver license numbers (or Social Security numbers if they have no license), and date of birth.

Yesterday marked the two-year anniversary of former President Barack Obama's deal with Iran. Two years later, the Iran deal is still a bad deal for the United States. Despite the U.S. honoring our side of the deal, Iran repeatedly has violated key clauses of the agreement. Reports indicate that Iran has not fully cooperated with IAEA inspectors and German intelligence officials recently reported that Iran is seeking nuclear technology outside of the bounds set by the agreement. When the Trump Administration delivers its report on the Iran deal later this month, I encourage the administration to certify Iran as non-compliant to the agreement. Additionally, it is time for Congress to pass new sanctions on Iran. We must begin reversing the damage done by the Iran deal before it is too late.

Currently, the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) provides headstones for veterans’ dependents whose remains can never be found. However, the guidelines are inconsistent for spouses and children. Today, I introduced a bill to level the playing field and ensure the VA is able to provide headstones to the children of veterans whose remains are unavailable, as well as spouses.   As the law stands today, the VA will provide headstones for veterans’ spouses who passed away after November 10, 1998, but will only do so for dependent children if they passed away after December 21, 2006. My bill would make the dates consistent, making them both the 1998 date. If enacted, my bill would better allow the VA to honor the lives of those veterans’ lost children who have passed away but have not been provided with a headstone.

Voters elected a Republican majority and a Republican Congress to change the status quo in Washington and “drain the swamp.” Increasingly it appears the opposite is happening.     Yesterday I voted for a bill that would provide $8 billion in immediate relief to address the damage done by Hurricane Harvey. This legislation passed the House, but after a meeting at the White House, President Trump, Nancy Pelosi, and Chuck Schumer agreed on a deal to attach a debt ceiling increase and government funding to this Harvey relief bill. The Senate will add these items, pass the bill, and send it back to the House.     This agreement is disappointing for two reasons. First, disaster relief funding should be about disaster relief, and nothing more. Attaching other issues to this bill plays politics with an issue that should rise above it. Secondly, with our country $20 trillion in debt, simply maintaining the status quo and allowing more debt to accumulate on the national credit card is unacceptable.   Republicans control the House, the Senate, and the White House, and we must work together on significant fiscal reforms. I will not support a debt ceiling increase that makes no effort to address our country’s debt problems.

Today I introduced a bill to update the Nunn–Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction program, an initiative based on legislation authored by Senators Sam Nunn (D-GA) and Richard Lugar (R-IN) in 1991 to dismantle nuclear, chemical and biological weapons in former Soviet states. My bill would ensure the effectiveness of the Nunn-Lugar program continues by directing federal research to examine future threats and how well the Nunn-Lugar program is structured to deal with them.  As I saw firsthand during a recent trip to Eastern Europe, the Nunn-Lugar program has been a huge success and made our world a safer place. The Nunn-Lugar program was established in 1991, but the threats we face have changed significantly since then. I want to ensure this program remains as effective today as it was when Senator Lugar originally established it in the 1990s. My bill would direct a study to look at the program’s structure to determine if it has evolved properly to address today’s threats. Updating the Nunn-Lugar program is an important way we can address the security threats we face today around the globe.

There has been a great deal of concern expressed about the “cost” of tax reform effort in Congress - with cost meaning reduced tax revenue. Putting aside the fact that this is not the government’s money in the first place, I believe this is the wrong way to look at the “cost” of any tax legislation. A recent post by the Tax Foundation illustrates this. It points out that the Joint Committee on Taxation estimates that the tax bills passed by the House and Senate will reduce government revenues by $1 trillion over a decade (for context, this means that instead of collecting $46 trillion in revenues over the next decade, the government will collect $45 trillion). The same analysis finds that the bills will increase economic growth by $1.67-$1.9 trillion over the same period (depending on whether you are looking at the House or the Senate bill). It is clear from these numbers that the economic growth generated from these tax cuts far outweighs their “cost” and will lead to more jobs and higher wages for middle-class Hoosier families.

The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act simplifies the tax code, allows Hoosiers to keep more of their money, unleashes job growth, eliminates special interest loopholes, and more. Today’s the day – let’s get this done.

Today is a good day for the future of the American dream. By passing this legislation, Congress has delivered on its promise to deliver sweeping tax reform to the American people for the first time since 1986. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will provide middle-class tax relief while promoting investment, job creation and sustained economic growth. It will lead to bigger paychecks for workers across our country and restore America’s global competitiveness. I commend Speaker Paul Ryan, Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady and members of the Conference Committee for their hard work that made this day possible. I look forward to swift passage in the Senate and President Trump signing this historic legislation into law.  The Conference Report to the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act passed the U.S. House of Representatives 227-203 The bill includes a series of provisions that will simplify the tax code and lower rates, allowing Hoosiers to keep more of their hard-earned money. The final bill also doubles the standard deduction to $12,000 and $24,000 for individuals and married couples respectively, while also expanding the Child Tax Credit. Businesses will experience much needed relief through a new deduction for pass-through entities, allowing Hoosier small businesses to make new investments. The legislation also boosts America’s global competitiveness by lowering the corporate tax rate to 21 percent.

Many constituents have asked about the latest with the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), which covers nine million children across our country. Unfortunately, due to comments by Jimmy Kimmel and others, the facts surrounding CHIP have become distorted.    Funding for CHIP technically expired on October 1, but states - including Indiana - have been operating the program with excess funds provided by the Department of Health and Human Services. On November 3, I voted for a bill to reauthorize CHIP for five years, a bill that passed the House of Representatives by a vote of 242-174. Most Republicans voted for this legislation with some support from Democrats. Unfortunately, the Senate never considered this bill.   This week I voted for a bill that fully funds CHIP for six months, backdated to October 1. Again, most Republicans voted for this bill and most Democrats voted against it. This time, the legislation passed both the House and Senate, and CHIP is now funded through the end of March 2018.   Despite the false claims of some, Republicans are not trying to take away health care coverage from children or hurt kids. In the coming weeks, I will continue working with my colleagues on a long-term, fiscally responsible re-authorization of CHIP. I hope many Democrats will join this effort and quit holding this issue hostage for political gain.
